historical_significance: Pioneer ancestor who crossed to Taiwan in 1746 [3], became prosperous, but was implicated and died during the Lin Shuang-wen Rebellion in 1788 [5, 6].

relation: Second younger brother of Lin Shi [8, 9]
Fifth younger brother of Lin Shi [8, 9]

historical_significance: Father of Mrs. Huang, intervened to prevent her departure from Taiwan [12].
Eldest son of Lin Chia-yin, founder of the Lower House lineage [3], local strongman, died 1848 [16].
Mother of Lin Wen-ming, a formidable matriarch who spent years seeking justice for her son [17, 18], died 1883 [18].
Son of Lin Ting-pang, strongman known for roughness and violence, died 1870 in Chang-hua yamen [3, 22]. His death led to protracted litigation for the family [23].

Eldest son of Lin Wen-ch'a, became leader of the Lower House, General who served in the Sino-French war, patron of Liu Ming-ch'uan [3, 26, 28]. Exiled himself to the mainland after 1895 [29], died 1904 [30].
Son of Lin Wenming. He was a poet and scholar during the Qing Dynasty and founded the traditional poetry society 'Qingshe' during the Japanese colonial period.

name.katakana: リンウェンミン キタイ エルズ

relation: Other sons of Lin Wenming (total 6 sons including Ch'ao-ch'ang, Ch'ao-hsuan, Chun-t'ang) [24, 35]

historical_significance: Son of Lin Ch'ao-tung [20]. Assumed control of his father's assets [39]. Expressed political commitment through military service on the mainland [40]. Born 1878, died 1925 [39].
Eldest son of Lin Ch'ao-hsuan, poet and cultural leader [36]. Born 1880, died 1939 [36]. Core member of the Oak Poetry Society [41].
Matriarch of the Upper House, known for warmth, generosity, and compassion [19], died 1921 [19].
Son of Lin Tien-kuo, disdained formal learning [1], died young in 1877 [1].

name.katakana: リンウェンチン ジチー
リンウェンチン チェ
リンウェンチン キタイ エルズ

note: A scholar in the Qing dynasty The head of the Japanese-ruled Wufeng Village

historical_significance: Daughter of 林獻堂, mentioned in the diary as being involved in family matters and receiving gifts [4, 7, 10, 12-15, 17].
note: Daughter of 林獻堂. Involved in family matters, mentioned in diary entries.
relation: Daughter of 林獻堂 and Lin Xiantang's Wife

historical_significance: Eldest son of Lin Tien-kuo, became leader of the Upper House branch after his father's imprisonment, known for using money and persuasion rather than force [9], died 1882 [9].

name.english: Daughter of 林帛亨 and Abby Fung

historical_significance: Son of 林獻堂. Mentioned in the diary [4, 7, 10, 12-15, 17], noted as being involved in the timber business (三振材木商行) [10].
note: Son of 林獻堂. His involvement in business is mentioned in the diary.
relation: Son of 林獻堂 and Lin Xiantang's Wife, Brother of 林擧龍 and 林猶龍

name.katakana: リン　ジョナサン　ロング

historical_significance: Eldest son of Lin Shi, businessman and peacemaker [10], died young at age 21 in 1780 [10].
Widow of Lin Sun, led the family to move to Wu-feng after the rebellion [11], died 1835 [5].
His descendants were middling farmers or small shopkeepers [14].

note: Head of the Taiping Lin family [13]

historical_significance: Son of Lin Sun, founder of the famous line in Wu-feng [13], businessman and landlord, died 1839 [14, 15].
Son of Lin Ting-pang, formidable strongman and General who served the Qing on the mainland and in Taiwan [3, 16], died in battle 1864 [20]. Posthumously granted high honors [20].

name.katakana: リンウェンチャ チーヒェ

historical_significance: Son of Lin Tien-kuo and Mrs. Lo [3, 17], became head of the Upper House branch in 1882 [26], known for supporting arts and social movements, acquired gentry degrees [3, 27], philanthropist, died 1899 [26].

note: A member of the Wufeng Lin family in Taichung City, Taiwan, he was the fourth son of Lin Jitang and the founder of the Red Clan in Taichung County, Taiwan[1]. He once served as the mayor of Taichung County.

name.katakana: リンウェンディエシュアン

historical_significance: Widow of Lin Wen-tien, raised their son Chi-t'ang with a sense of responsibility [37].

Eldest son of Lin Wen-ch'in [1], prominent cultural leader, poet, and leader of the Taiwanese autonomy movement [2]. Born 1881, died 1956 [1]. Accompanied by his son Lin Youlong on a trip in 1936 [4].
A leading Taiwanese contemporary painter and conceptual artist
Son of 林獻堂. Frequently mentioned in the diary, involved in family affairs, accompanying his father on visits and trips [4, 7, 8, 10, 12-17]. Noted as being involved in inspecting accounts [10].
note: Son of 林獻堂. Appears frequently in diary entries, involved in family business/affairs.
relation: Son of 林獻堂 and Lin Xiantang's Wife, Brother of 林擧龍 and 林猶龍

note: A Taiwanese female artist, she is known as 'Little Lin Chi-ling' for her sweet baby voice and beauty that resembles supermodel Lin Chi-ling.

name.hanzi: Mother of Miss Ho (first and second wife)
name.pinyin: Mother of Miss Ho (first and second wife)
name.english: Mother of Miss Ho (first and second wife)

name.katakana: リンウェンミン セイサイ

historical_significance: Mother of Lin Ch'ao-hsuan [24], died 1883 [18].

name.katakana: リンウェンミン チェ

historical_significance: Had descendants, received little from the common estate [25].
Wife of Lin Ch'ao-tung, known for strong will and intelligence, rescued her husband during a siege [21, 30, 31].

relation: Second wife of Lin Ch'ao-hsuan, sister of his first wife [24]

name.katakana: リンウェンチン チー

historical_significance: Adulterous first wife of Lin Wen-ch'in, sent back to her family [19].

relation: Son of Lin Zhengguang and Lin Fanying

note: a Taiwanese racing driver and Elda Formula One race commentator. The Japanese call him 'Fire Fox'. He won the 2005 Asian Formula Renault championship and served as a Formula One race commentator for TVSports and FOX Sports.

relation: Third younger brother of Lin Shi [8, 9]
Forth younger brother of Lin Shi [8, 9]
Sixth younger brother of Lin Shi [8, 9]

historical_significance: Had a marginal status in the family [13].

relation: Eldest son of Lin Ch'ao-tung and Mrs. Yang [32]

historical_significance: Adopted sixth son of Lin Wenming, poet [36].

name.katakana: ホシ (ファーストワイフ)

relation: First wife of Lin Ch'ao-hsuan, sister of his second wife [24]

historical_significance: Second son of Lin Ch'ao-tung, poet [36].

name.katakana: リンウェンディエシュアン

historical_significance: Widow of Lin Wen-tien, raised their son Chi-t'ang with a sense of responsibility [37].
Son of Lin Chia-yin, founder of the Upper House lineage [3], local strongman, involved in military service [16], died in jail in 1880 [9].

name.katakana: リンティエンクオ チーヒェ

note: Son of 林獻堂. Plays an active role assisting his father according to the diary entries.
relation: Son of 林獻堂 and Lin Xiantang's Wife, Brother of 林猶龍 and 林雲龍

historical_significance: Chairman of Ming Tai Property & Casualty Insurance

name.katakana: ハヤシショウリのムスコ
